- Item 2: scrutiny session with focus on higher and further education. Kirsty Williams talked about teacher training, secondary school teachers, Welsh teacher training centres. Accreditation process for new ITE provision starting next academic year. Financial incentives: £20k a year for high-qualifying graduates. National ITE recruitment marketing exercise targeting Welsh students, e-mailing them, sending materials to consider becoming teacher and training in Wales. Full national programme of ITE recruitment. Also set up advisory board on recruitment and retention of teaching staff, awaiting reports.

- Suzy Davies asked about reasons why people don't want to become teachers. Kirsty said it's not unique to Wales; similar issues across border; money isn't the only answer. Research shows teacher recruitment is a global issue. They have employment-based routes into qualified teacher status (training on job). They increased those places to 90 last year and again this year, and will have part-time PGCE route next year.

- Suzy asked about Welsh medium teaching: why not more? Kirsty said data for 2018-19 cohort not yet available. Difference between people who are on courses with designation to teach through medium of Welsh vs those with linguistic ability but no course. For 2016-17 cohort, additional 130 qualifiers fluent in Welsh didn't do a course that gave them that designation. They have new incentives this year for starting their course and for teachers completing QTS after a year.

- Llyr Gruffydd asked about targets: they need to double numbers; lost 24% of people going into teacher training to study subjects they could teach through medium of Welsh. Kirsty said there are statistics, but more work needed with ITE providers.

- Eluned Morgan talked about diversity in teaching workforce, career changers, etc.

Thus answer: They discussed that recruitment is only at ~65% for priority places; reasons include global shortage, not just money, lack of awareness, need to improve ITE provision, accreditation, financial incentives, national marketing targeting Welsh students, employment-based routes, part-time PGCE, advisory board. Steps taken: world-class ITE, new accreditation process, financial incentives (£20k), national recruitment campaign, advisory board on recruitment and retention, increased places for employment-based routes, plan to introduce part-time PGCE route.

* **Recruitment figures** – The group noted that only about **65 % of priority places in Welsh teacher‑training centres are currently filled**, and that the trend is still a problem for secondary‑school teachers and priority subjects.

* **Why it’s hard to recruit** –  
  * It isn’t a uniquely Welsh issue; similar shortages exist across the border and worldwide.  
  * Money alone won’t solve it – research shows that financial incentives are only part of the answer.  
  * Many people who could become teachers simply aren’t aware of the routes or don’t see teaching as a viable career.

* **What’s being done** – The Cabinet Secretary outlined several fronts:  

  1. **World‑class ITE provision** – accreditation processes for new teacher‑training programmes that will start next academic year.  
  2. **Financial incentives** – £20 k per year for graduates who qualify at the highest level, plus other financial support for those starting and completing QTS.  
  3. **National recruitment marketing** – A full national ITE recruitment exercise targeting Welsh students (e‑mails, materials, etc.) to raise awareness that training can be done in Wales.  
  4. **Employment‑based routes** – The number of places for “training on the job” has been increased to 90 last year and again this year; a new part‑time PGCE route will be introduced next year so people can combine work, study and earn while learning.  
  5. **Advisory board** – An advisory board on recruitment and retention of teaching staff is set up (under Prof John Gardner) to produce reports on what’s working and what isn’t.

* **Other points raised** – The group also discussed the need for more Welsh‑medium teachers, noting that a gap still exists between those who are fluent in Welsh and those who actually take a course that gives them the designation to teach through the medium of Welsh. New incentives this year aim to address that too.

In short, the committee acknowledged that recruitment is still below target, identified that it’s a global issue not solved by money alone, and reviewed the multi‑pronged strategy being implemented – accreditation, financial incentives, national marketing, employment‑based routes, part‑time PGCE and an advisory board – to boost numbers of qualified teachers.

The committee asked whether any university governing bodies were showing an *imprudent* appetite for risk.  
Dr David Blaney answered that HEFCW does not see evidence of such behaviour.  The organisation monitors risk appetite in two ways:

1. **Forecasts and borrowing requests** – the universities’ five‑year forecasts and their requests for new borrowings are examined closely; any overly optimistic or risky assumptions would be flagged.

2. **External perspective & questioning** – HEFCW keeps an external eye on how institutions perform, asking the right questions and providing guidance rather than dictating decisions.  

In short, HEFCW’s solution is to monitor risk appetite through forecasts/borrowings and by asking the right questions, ensuring that governing bodies are making prudent, not imprudent, choices.

*Date:* 12 May 2024  
*Chair:* Lynne Neagle AM  

The committee met online with all members present via video‑conference. The meeting was held in accordance with Standing Order 34.19 (public excluded) but broadcast live on Senedd.tv. After a brief procedural opening, the chair moved to an evidence session with senior ministers from the Welsh Government.

**Key points discussed**

| Topic | Main issues raised | Ministerial responses |
|-------|--------------------|----------------------|
| **Impact of COVID‑19 on children and young people** | Transmission role of children; school reopening; capacity for paediatric care; mental health impact. | Ministers acknowledged that children are less likely to be severely affected but can still transmit the virus. They confirmed that paediatric surge capacity exists, though it is a challenge when schools reopen. Mental‑health services remain essential and crisis care continues 7 days a week. |
| **Health & social service provision** | Routine visits, vaccinations, immunisation programmes; fear of parents not attending. | Health visiting service remains active; vaccination programme continued; efforts to reassure parents that routine care is safe. |
| **Mental health & wellbeing** | Assessment of impact on children’s mental health; suicide risk; crisis services. | Ongoing monitoring via weekly data collection; a review commissioned to assess unexpected deaths and potential rise in suicides. Crisis care remains available. |
| **Perinatal support** | Support for new mothers during pandemic. | Perinatal mental‑health service continues, with phone/online options where possible. |
| **Child protection & safeguarding** | Impact on child protection referrals; vulnerable children; technology access. | Local authorities encouraged to keep vulnerable children in school or childcare settings; 890 vulnerable children attending schools. Social workers maintain contact via technology; no relaxation of statutory requirements. |
| **Look‑after and foster care** | Residential homes, foster carers, care leavers. | No major issues reported; residential homes functioning well; support for foster carers through local authorities. |
| **Third‑sector & childcare funding** | Funding gaps in childcare sector; need for bespoke grant package. | Ministers explained existing funding streams (economic resilience fund, job retention scheme, etc.) and acknowledged difficulties with double‑funding rules. They were working to develop a specific support package for providers that have not yet received aid. |
| **Legislation & impact assessments** | Whether children’s rights impact assessments were carried out under new coronavirus regulations. | No easements introduced; impact assessments still being undertaken, though rapid legislation made it difficult. A survey of children was announced to capture their views on the pandemic. |
| **Family courts** | Virtual hearings; child arrangement orders. | Many hearings virtualised; complex cases postponed; guidance issued for parents and families. |

The chair thanked ministers and officials for their time and concluded that the committee would now meet in private for the remainder of the meeting, noting that this was the last formal business before the National Assembly’s next session.

Overall, the committee reviewed how Welsh Government services are adapting to COVID‑19 for children and young people, confirmed ongoing support across health, education, safeguarding and third‑sector areas, and discussed funding challenges in childcare. Ministers emphasised continued monitoring, crisis care provision, and efforts to keep vulnerable children connected with social workers and technology.

| **Bindings & attributes** | The sheet now contains slots for attribute–value pairs (e.g., number, gender, aspect). * **What a mental space is**  
  * A temporary “world” or situation created (or modified) when an utterance is processed.

* **When a new space is created**

* **Nested / hierarchical spaces**

* **What it’s used for**

So, there's a whole package of things we need to do."

So, that proves to me—what the research does show—that it's not money alone that will get people onto these courses. Interestingly, I don't even think it's a UK problem. Recently, as you'll be aware via my written statement, I attended the Atlantic Rim Collaboratory, which is a system-to-system conference.
